comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/joseph-jb7] Hello Joseph. The photographer in this instance was Colman Doyle, whose name you will see in the tags for this photo. That is the convention we use here. It has arisen in many cases because dealing as we do with historical collections, it is very often uncertain who took the photograph in question. The NLI ref. link below every image we post, in this case CDOY83 brings you into our National Library of Ireland catalogue, to other work by that photographer if known, or to a particular collection of photographs that can then be explored further.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 15372619@N05
comment._content:
The tags list is only of any use on this page. Since the picture has been stripped of all EXIF data, the picture is orphaned as soon as it's copied and pasted. Regarding the Copyright restrictions on this page, they don't match the copyright restrictions linked to in the description. In all, I think the curatorship of the pictures uploaded by the National Gallery is sloppy, and falls below the standards of any other gallery I've seen. It's around the standard of any picture copied and posted on Facebook, unfortunately.

I enjoy the pictures posted here, but an explicit credit is the minimum standard for the creator of an artwork, and that should be incorporated into the EXIF too, as well as other information, such as licensing details.

That, I think, is the problem, though I'm not at all surprised that others think there is no problem. As I said, I enjoy the pictures posted here, I just think the photographs and the photographers deserve a little more respect. I've stated my position, I don't expect to re-state it or add to it, so I'll be leaving this discussion. I hope the new convention is continued, and that the cataloguing improves- it is a National Institution, after all...

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/joseph-jb7] Hello again, Joseph. I'm sorry that you think the curatorship is sloppy, but our reason for being here is to share our photos and hopefully elicit information and prompt discussion on them. We are not here to broadcast each and every detail in our catalogue about individual photos, but we most certainly do respect our photographers and their photographs in our care that represent well over a century and a half of dedication, hard work, and very often artistry on their part.

And we're not the National Gallery.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 80456351@N00
comment._content:
Oh, and just wanted to add that I love the job Carol and her trusty crack band of Flickroonies do. This is using the social media features of the 'net to their finest. The experience takes something that could be static and turns it into a living history lesson, combining the best of everyone's wisdom, memories, research, and remarks about dogs, and yet feels like friends having a chat.

And there's no such thing as a non sequitur here.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
Well, I never! Can't find this photograph in the Irish Press where Colman Doyle was a staff photographer - maybe it was never printed? However, did find out more about our model, Linda O'Reilly in an article (Tuesday, 28 November 1961) about Brendan O'Reilly who used to present Sports Stadium on RTÉ Television:
... In England he married Linda Ward, an American fashion model whome he met in New York, and they both returned to Ireland a year and a half ago. ... Linda O'Reilly, Brendan's tall, dark and very beautiful wife, has resumed her career as a model, since she settled down in Dublin, with the Miriam Woodbyrne Agency. A native of New Jersey, and a graduate of the University of Vermont, she was successfully launced on a career as a model in New York, when her meeting with Brendan O'Reilly disturbed her plans. Linda has a very interesting family background. Her grandmother was Daisy Linda Travers Ward, a famous operatic singer - she sang in Covent Garden in 1919 and 1920..."
So, Linda O'Reilly was in Ireland from about May 1960? Gives us our earliest date - what do we think?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Hold everything! Searched for Linda Ward in the Irish Press and found a photo from Monday, 18 January 1960. She was already married and working in Ireland then - described as top U.S. fashion model and quoted as saying "Irish photographers are much more easy to please than Americans. It was so nice posing for them". So this photo has to be from January 1960 onwards, unless of course, any of you know different...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/77199267@N03] When I worked in the area in the late '60's early 70's it was full of Solicitors offices! [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] I have seen this shot before and am pretty certain that it was in print, if not the newspaper then in magazines or books relating to the history of that time in Dublin! I note that this shot comes up in the NUI Galway site as in www.google.ie/imgres?imgurl=http://www.nuigalway.ie/media...

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: I went a-seeking information about Gorman in our Thoms Dublin Directories. His name was Patrick Gorman. He was a pawnbroker and was at 19 & 20 Winetavern Street (also 31 James's Street). By 1965, Mr Gorman was listing himself as a pawnbroker and a jeweller. By 1966, Mr Gorman had decamped to Cuffe Street...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
